Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A High-Resolution Digital Fingertip
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to bring to the market a high-resolution digital fingertip: an easy-to-use, compact, and compliant sensor that will provide human-like tactile sensing. Such a sensor can be used to automate assembly tasks in next-generation factories, enable smart objects to understand their tactile environment, and equip scientists with a finger-like sensor for studying human touch. Industries have been transformed by the digitization of our auditory and visual worlds. A high-resolution digital fingertip will provide the mechanism for digitizing the tactile world leading to applications and technological developments that will touch many industries.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop a compact, compliant, and high-resolution tactile sensor based on GelSight elastomeric imaging technology. This project proposes a modular optical and illumination architecture for GelSight imaging that will create the appropriate conditions for 3D measurement in a compact package. The modular system can be tiled to cover a large field of view without increasing the device thickness. This effort will lead to new insight into illumination design for shading-based 3D measurement as well as optimizations to allow for real-time tactile information. The system will be coupled with a software development kit (SDK) that provides real-time tactile information, including contact locations, contact force and contact shape. The SDK will make the system accessible to researchers and engineers from other disciplines, which is essential for the successful commercialization of the technology. The high-resolution digital fingertip, together with the SDK, will provide a foundation for further exploration into digital touch as well as applications that benefit from tactile information.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is no tactile sensor on the market today with all the properties of the human finger: compact, soft and high-resolution. Current technologies either measure point force, but are not soft, or use capacitive sensors, which are not high-resolution and therefore do not provide the sensory input of human touch. The lack of such a sensor is limiting the ability of robots and other intelligent systems to perform tasks that require detailed tactile information. Moreover, our understanding of human tactile perception is limited and would greatly benefit from a sensor that could measure a signal that is comparable to the human finger. This project explored optical and illumination configuration for developing a compact, soft and high-resolution digital fingertip based on the GelSight elastomeric sensor. An early prototype of the digital fingertip was deployed to early adopters for use in robotics research. Future versions of this system can be deployed by system integrators to equip robots with tactile sensing, which is essential in many complex manufacturing and assembly tasks that are being performed by humans today. The sensor will also help scientists explore the mysteries of human touch.

Phase I of the project explored a modular optical and illumination system that will create the appropriate conditions for 3D measurement in a compact package that could ultimately provide human-like tactile input for robots. This optical configuration will allow for a dramatic shrinking of the form factor which is essential in creating a practical digital fingertip that mimics human touch. This effort led to new insights into illumination design for shading-based 3D measurement. An initial software SDK allows the system to be used by researchers and engineers from other disciplines, which is essential for the successful commercialization of the technology. The Phase I effort demonstrated feasibility of the design without requiring new equipment or customized hardware. 

An easy to use compact, compliant, and high-resolution sensor will provide human-like tactile sensing to robots, spurring the automation of manufacturing, picking, and assembly tasks in next-generation factories. This innovation will enable smart objects that understand their environment and equip scientists with a tool to study human touch. Commercialization of this breakthrough will make U.S. manufacturers more competitive in markets that are currently labor-intensive due to the limitations of robotic touch, providing economic advantage and cost savings in production. This innovation should also lead to significant improvements in the capabilities of prosthetics and artificial limbs. Industries have been transformed by the digitization of our auditory and visual worlds. A High-Resolution Digital Fingertip will provide the mechanism for digitizing the tactile world leading to applications and technological developments that cannot be imagined today.
